slides.title: Introduction to Forms
slides.content:
# Interaction on the Web üìù

HTML Forms are the primary way websites collect data from users. 

## What are they used for?
- **Login / Registration** üîê
- **Search boxes** üîç
- **Feedback surveys** üìä
- **Checkout pages** üõí

The `<form>` element is a container for different types of input elements.

slides.title: The <form> Element
slides.content:
# The <form> Element üì®

The `<form>` element defines an HTML form for user input.

```html_not
<form action="/submit-data" method="POST">
  <!-- input elements go here -->
</form>
```

## Key Attributes
- **action:** Where to send the form-data when submitted (URL).
- **method:** The HTTP method to use (usually `GET` or `POST`).
  - `GET`: Appends data to URL (insecure, good for search).
  - `POST`: Sends data in request body (secure, good for passwords).

slides.title: The <input> Element
slides.content:
# The <input> Element ‚å®Ô∏è

The most important form element is the `<input>` element. It changes appearance based on the `type` attribute.

## Common Input Types

| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| `text` | Single-line text field |
| `password` | Masked characters |
| `email` | Validates email format |
| `number` | Numeric input only |
| `date` | Date picker |

```html_not
<input type="text" placeholder="Enter your name">
```

slides.title: Labels
slides.content:
# The <label> Element üè∑Ô∏è

The `<label>` element represents a caption for an item in a user interface.

## Why use labels?
1. **Accessibility:** Screen readers read out the label when the user focuses on the input.
2. **Usability:** Clicking the label focuses the input field.

## Connecting Label and Input
The `for` attribute of the label should match the `id` of the input.

```html
<label for="username">Username:</label>
<input type="text" id="username" name="username">
```

slides.title: Select Dropdown
slides.content:
# The <select> Element üîΩ

The `<select>` element defines a drop-down list.

- The `<option>` elements define the available options.
- Use the `selected` attribute to pre-select an option.

```html
<label for="cars">Choose a car:</label>

<select name="cars" id="cars">
  <option value="volvo">Volvo</option>
  <option value="saab">Saab</option>
  <option value="mercedes">Mercedes</option>
  <option value="audi">Audi</option>
</select>
```

slides.title: Buttons
slides.content:
# The <button> Element üîò

The `<button>` element defines a clickable button.

Unlike `<input type="button">`, you can put content inside the `<button>` element, like text or images.

```html
<button type="button" onclick="alert('Hello World!')">
  Click Me!
</button>
```

- `type="submit"`: Submits a form (default inside forms).
- `type="reset"`: Resets form inputs.
- `type="button"`: Does nothing unless scripted.

slides.title: Form Attributes
slides.content:
# Important Form Attributes ‚öôÔ∏è

## The Name Attribute
Each input field must have a `name` attribute to be submitted.

```html_not
<input type="text" name="lastname">
```

## The Value Attribute
Specifies an initial value for an input field.

```html_not
<input type="text" name="fname" value="John">
```

## The Readonly Attribute
The `readonly` attribute specifies that an input field is read-only.

```html_not
<input type="text" name="country" value="Norway" readonly>
```

slides.title: Disabled and Size
slides.content:
# Disabled & Size üö´

## The Disabled Attribute
Specifies that an input field should be disabled. Disabled elements are un-clickable and valid input is not sent on submit.

```html_not
<input type="text" name="lname" disabled>
```

## The Size Attribute
Specifies the visible width of an input field (in characters).

```html_not
<input type="text" name="fname" size="50">
```

slides.title: Datalist
slides.content:
# The <datalist> Element üìã

The `<datalist>` element specifies a list of pre-defined options for an `<input>` element.

Users will see a drop-down list of options as they input data.

- The `list` attribute of the input must refer to the `id` attribute of the datalist.

```html
<form>
  <input list="browsers" name="browser">
  <datalist id="browsers">
    <option value="Edge">
    <option value="Firefox">
    <option value="Chrome">
    <option value="Opera">
    <option value="Safari">
  </datalist>
</form>
```

slides.title: Forms Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: HTML Forms üéì

You are now ready to collect user data!

- **`<form>`**: The container.
- **`<input>`**: The versatile soldier (`text`, `radio`, `checkbox`, `submit`, `password`, `email`).
- **`<label>`**: Essential for accessibility and usability.
- **`<select>` & `<textarea>`**: For lists and long text.
- **Validation**: Use `required`, `min`, `max`, `type="email"`.

## Pro Tip
Always use meaningful `name` attributes for your inputs, or the server won't know what data it's receiving!
